title: What’s Behind the Pileup of Sex Abuse Scandals?
description: Sociologists see a pattern that goes beyond the culture of specific schools, churches and industries: an ingrained resistance to self-policing or defying a community’s hierarchy.

title: Teenagers Died of Asphyxiation in South Africa Tavern, Parents Are Told
description: Health officials met with families that had waited more than two months to learn why 21 teenagers died one June night in an overcrowded bar.

title: U.S. Restricts Sales of Sophisticated Chips to China and Russia
description: Limits were placed on high-end GPUs that power supercomputers and artificial intelligence, said Nvidia and AMD, two Silicon Valley chip makers.

title: Your Thursday Briefing: U.N. Accuses China of Possible ‘Crimes Against Humanity’
description: Plus U.N. inspects an embattled nuclear power plant and China locks down Chengdu.

title: For China’s Xi and Other Strongmen, Gorbachev Showed Exactly What Not to Do
description: Though Mikhail Gorbachev’s reforms were praised in the West, the collapse of the Soviet Union schooled a generation of authoritarian rulers in the dangers of tolerating any signs of dissent or democratic yearnings.

title: With war raging near the plant, what can the U.N. inspectors accomplish?
First Day of School in Ukraine, Upended by the Bleak Season of War
description: For those lucky enough to have schools to return to, back-to-school day is still colored by war. Schools must now have bomb shelters, and first-aid kits are handed out along with pens and paper.

title: At Shakespeare’s Globe, a Nonbinary Joan of Arc Causes a Stir
description: Even before the production debuted, it had inflamed a rancorous debate about sex and gender that plays out almost daily in Britain.

title: Russian Defector Describes Putin’s Military in Disarray in Ukraine
description: Pavel Filatiev has been greeted as a hero by some in the West but is seen as a scourge in his native country for criticizing what he called Russia’s “terrible war.”

title: Spain Offers Free Train Tickets Through End of Year
description: Rail passengers will be able to take free train journeys under 300 kilometers (186 miles) until the end of the year.

title: Debt-Stricken Sri Lanka Reaches Initial Deal for I.M.F. Bailout
description: The package includes nearly $3 billion in loans for an island nation that ousted its president amid a devastating economic crisis.

title: Why NASA Wants to Go Back to the Moon
description: Why NASA wants to go back now.

title: Pencil, chalk and first-aid kits: Ukrainian children return to school in the midst of war.
description: An estimated 2.8 million of the nation’s six million children have been forced from their homes because of the war. If they are fortunate enough to find a seat in a classroom, it will probably be in an unfamiliar town or city.

title: For Uyghurs, U.N. Report on China’s Abuses Is Long-Awaited Vindication
description: The report’s assessment that China’s crackdown in Xinjiang could amount to “crimes against humanity” gives new momentum to a campaign to pressure Beijing.

title: Will a Renewed Iran Nuclear Deal Cut Energy Prices?
description: A successful deal to restrain Iran’s nuclear program would mean that Washington lifts tough sanctions on Iran’s oil and gas exports. But it may already be too late for that to help this winter.

title: China May Have Committed ‘Crimes Against Humanity’ in Xinjiang, U.N. Says
description: The organization’s human rights office delivered its much-delayed report minutes before Michelle Bachelet, the U.N. high commissioner for human rights, was to leave office.

title: In a Japanese Nursing Home, Some Workers Are Babies
description: They get paid in formula and diapers, and their work hours are flexible, in a program that connects people across generations and brightens lives.

title: Nuclear monitors aim to reach the Zaporizhzhia plant on Thursday.
Your Thursday Briefing
description: Vladimir Putin reacts to Mikhail Gorbachev’s death.

title: ‘Absolute Warfare’: Cartels Terrorize Mexico as Security Forces Fall Short
description: The president disbanded the Federal Police and created the National Guard to tackle soaring violence, but three years later, criminal cartels have expanded their reach.

title: A Draft for Russia’s Army? Putin Opts for Domestic Stability Instead.
description: Western officials are puzzled by the Russian leader’s decision to avoid mass conscription. But analysts say he is intent on maintaining a sense of normalcy to prevent any public backlash.

title: How Reagan and Bush Overcame Their Skepticism of Gorbachev
description: Mr. Gorbachev was charming and presented himself as a modernizer, but neither Ronald Reagan nor George Bush was convinced he was for real. They would both be proved wrong.

title: Bolsonaro Allies and Election Officials Reach Truce on Voting Machines
description: President Jair Bolsonaro has claimed that Brazil’s voting machines are vulnerable to fraud, with little evidence. Election officials agreed to explore changes to security tests before the October election.
